name: Chinese dumplings (Potstickers!)
description: Recipe video above. Time to get your dumpling game on! Don't fret about perfect pleats - if it's all too hard, just press the seams together without pleating, plenty of Chinese restaurants do this.Â This recipe has a pork and cabbage filling, which is traditional and common. After a Vegetable filling? Here it is!
recipeIngredient: 1 Â½ cups finely chopped Chinese cabbage ((Napa cabbage))
250 g / 0.5 lb   fatty pork mince ((20 - 30% fat ideal - Note 2))
Â¼ cup garlic chives (, finely chopped*)
2 tsp light soy sauce ((light or dark soy also ok))
Â¼ tsp white pepper ((black also ok))

recipeInstructions.text: Shiitake Mushroom: Place the mushrooms in a bowl and pour over plenty of boiled water. Leave for 20 minutes or until rehydrated. Squeeze out excess water, then finely chop.
recipeInstructions.name: Shiitake Mushroom: Place the mushrooms in a bowl and pour over plenty of boiled water. Leave for 20 minutes or until rehydrated. Squeeze out excess water, then finely chop.

recipeInstructions.text: Cabbage: Place cabbage in a bowl with salt. Toss with fingers, then set aside for 15 minutes. Squeeze out excess liquid from cabbage using hands.
recipeInstructions.name: Cabbage: Place cabbage in a bowl with salt. Toss with fingers, then set aside for 15 minutes. Squeeze out excess liquid from cabbage using hands.

recipeInstructions.text: Filling: Place cabbage, mushrooms and remaining Filling ingredients in a bowl. Mix with your hands until well combined.
recipeInstructions.name: Filling: Place cabbage, mushrooms and remaining Filling ingredients in a bowl. Mix with your hands until well combined.
Make Dumplings (watch video + see photos in post):

itemListElement.text: Peel one wrapper off and place on the palm of your left hand (if right handed). Dip your finger in water and run it along half the edge of the wrapper.
itemListElement.name: Peel one wrapper off and place on the palm of your left hand (if right handed). Dip your finger in water and run it along half the edge of the wrapper.

itemListElement.text: Place 1 heaped tablespoon of Filling in the centre. Fold wrapper over, then pleat to seal. Alternatively, just press together with no pleats.
itemListElement.name: Place 1 heaped tablespoon of Filling in the centre. Fold wrapper over, then pleat to seal. Alternatively, just press together with no pleats.

itemListElement.text: Finish so the dumpling is curved slightly, see photos in post, with the pleats on the top.
itemListElement.name: Finish so the dumpling is curved slightly, see photos in post, with the pleats on the top.

itemListElement.text: Place on tray. Cover with cling wrap or wet tea towel (important). Repeat with remaining dumplings. Should make 30, if yours are extremely plump you may only make 25.
itemListElement.name: Place on tray. Cover with cling wrap or wet tea towel (important). Repeat with remaining dumplings. Should make 30, if yours are extremely plump you may only make 25.

itemListElement.text: Make sure your pan has a lid that fits it half decently (Note 6).
itemListElement.name: Make sure your pan has a lid that fits it half decently (Note 6).

itemListElement.text: Heat 2 tsp oil in a non stick pan over medium high heat. Add dumplings, pressing down firmly to flatten the base onto the pan. Cook around 8 to 10 per batch.
itemListElement.name: Heat 2 tsp oil in a non stick pan over medium high heat. Add dumplings, pressing down firmly to flatten the base onto the pan. Cook around 8 to 10 per batch.

itemListElement.text: When the base is golden brown (check them), add 1/2 cup of water into the pan.
itemListElement.name: When the base is golden brown (check them), add 1/2 cup of water into the pan.

itemListElement.text: Immediately clamp the lid on, then leave for 7 minutes (any less and the pleats won't be cooked through so if your water dries out, add a bit more).
itemListElement.name: Immediately clamp the lid on, then leave for 7 minutes (any less and the pleats won't be cooked through so if your water dries out, add a bit more).

itemListElement.text: Remove lid - most of the water should be evaporated, the pleats should be cooked through. Leave the pan on the stove until the base dries and the underside of the dumplings are once again crisp.
itemListElement.name: Remove lid - most of the water should be evaporated, the pleats should be cooked through. Leave the pan on the stove until the base dries and the underside of the dumplings are once again crisp.

itemListElement.text: Remove dumplings from pan and transfer to serving plate. Repeat with remaining Dumplings.
itemListElement.name: Remove dumplings from pan and transfer to serving plate. Repeat with remaining Dumplings.

itemListElement.text: Serve with Dipping Sauces of choice. (Note 7)
itemListElement.name: Serve with Dipping Sauces of choice. (Note 7)

review.reviewBody: Great recipe, very flavourful dumplings. I used spring onions in place of garlic chives and also whizzed up some carrot as I had a lone one in the fridge. Worked beautifully.

Another fantastic recipe. I used regular mushrooms also, and pulsed in kitchen aid first, also used scallions instead of garlic chives.
Absolutely delicious ðŸ¤¤ I wish my wrapping skills were better thoughðŸ¤ª
Great recipe - worked perfectly - even for a novice!! Appreciated by all - a great start to the new year of The Dragon

Hi Linda, yesterday I made Nagi's spring rolls and thought the same. I gave up trying to chop them finely and ran them through the meat grinder on my Kitchen Aid before I ground the pork. Did the same today with these babies. Worked a treat. Hopefully you have a grinder. Best of luck.
S x

Hi Nagi, just made these, they're not cooked yet but I know they'll taste great as I fried up the tiny left over filling and ate it. Lovely. Just thought I'd let you know too that the pleating was dead easy. First couple were a bit wonky but no problem after I'd got the hang of it. 30 filled and pleated in under 15 minutes. Thanks again.  Siu Mai and wontons tomorrow all ready for Sunday yum cha. Can't wait!
Cheers S

My first time ever as an adult of Chinese background ever attempting dumplings (we've only ever bought store bought ones before) and even my parents approve! I walked into an Asian butcher and asked them to mince the pork belly for me and the dumplings sure are juicy. I used them as wontons for our noodle soup and they are sooooo delicious!

These were amazing, made exactly as directed.
Honestly I will never buy premade dumplings again.

Made these for dinner tonight for my husband and myself and they were amazing! Instead of hand chopping the ingredients I pulsed them all separately in a small chopper. We both dislike mushrooms but I kept them in and we were both in love with these! Thank you Nagi for another perfect recipe!

This recipe is great! I've made dumplings with purchased wrappers before and was disappointed. Your detailed and foolproof cooking technique made all the difference.
After enjoying them I must agree with your assertion that fat is critical. I could have added more to the lean-ish ground pork I used, and will use at least the recommended added oil or fat. 
I look forward to the next delicious dumpling festival starring your great recipe!

I bought the wrong wrappers so I had to do a noodle skillet dish instead.    

Added Chicken broth,  oil for wok, green onions, sesame seed oil.  I think that is about it.   

Love your recipes!!   Just a few additions to make a sauce and there you have it.

These are by far the best dumplings I have made.
I cooked them as a starter for our New Yearâ€™s eve dinner and they were a massive success. People could not get enough of them.

Thank you SO MUCH for sharing the recipe and for making it easy to follow.

With love and gratitude.

Happy 2023!

Isabella
Cant get enough of these dumplings! Served with a veg lo mein (your recipe, of course). Incredible!

keywords: Chinese dumplings, Chinese Pan Fried Dumplings, Potstickers
